text.headline: Trump Declares Nuclear Ambitions
text.text:
Donald Trump proclaims he wants to negotiate nuclear deals with Russia. Backed by Roy Cohn, the political operative who advised Joe McCarthy and Richard Nixon, Trump said “It would take an hour-and-a-half to learn everything there is to learn about missiles. I think I know most of it anyway. You're talking about just getting updated on a situation… You know who really wants me to do this? Roy… I'd do it in a second.”

Source: Washington Post

media.url: He would know what to ask the Russians for, he says. But he would rather not tip his hand publicly. “In the event anything happens with respect to me, I wouldn't want to make my opinions public,” he says. “I'd rather keep those thoughts to myself or save them for whoever else is chosen . . .”
media.caption: Donald Trump as reported by the Washington Post, November 15, 1984

text.headline: UN Ambassador Churkin Meets Trump
text.text:
Recently deceased Russian Ambassador to the UN Vitaly Churkin first meets Donald Trump. Churkin would speak glowingly about this meeting during Trump’s campaign after Trump commented that Crimea had chosen to be a part of Russia.

Source: TASS

media.url: “You know, I was impressed by his energetic, open approach to doing business. Such are my personal recollections going some thirty years back.”
media.caption: UN Ambassador Vitaly Churkin on August 1, 2016 as reported by TASS

text.headline: Trump Plans Moscow Hotel
text.text:
Soviet ambassador Yuri Dubinin meets Donald Trump at a New York lunch. Trump would later recall how the conversation ended with him planning to build a luxury hotel across the street from the Kremlin. Trump then flew to Moscow at Dubinin’s invitation to discuss the hotel project with the Soviet tourism agency.

Source: Financial Times

media.url: “One thing led to another, and now I’m talking about building a large luxury hotel across the street from the Kremlin in partnership with the Soviet government.”
media.caption: Donald Trump describing meeting Ambassador Dubinin at a lunch in 1986

text.headline: Soviet Tourism Agency Contacts Trump
text.text:
Intourist, the Soviet agency for international tourism, reaches out to Donald Trump about a meeting. Trump and then-wife Ivana then flew to Moscow later that year to tour potential Trump Moscow sites and meet with economic and political advisers.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Meets with Politburo
text.text:
Donald Trump travels to Russia to explore building a hotel in coordination with Politburo officials. “He met with a lot of the economic and financial advisers in the Politburo,” said Trump spokesman Dan Klores.

Source: Washington Post

media.caption: 4 Staraya Square, Moscow, Headquarters of Politburo

text.headline: Trump Proposes Nuclear Alliance with USSR
text.text:
Trump proposes that US and Russia partner to form a single nuclear superpower to intimidate other countries into submission.

“Most of those [pre-nuclear] countries are in one form or another dominated by the US and the Soviet Union…Between those two nations you have the power to dominate any of those countries. So we should use our power of economic retaliation and they use their powers of retaliation, and between the two of us we will prevent the problem from happening. It would have been better having done something five years ago. But I believe even a country such as Pakistan would have to do something now. Five years from now they’ll laugh.”

Donald Trump speaking to Ron Rosenbaum at Club 21, New York City, 1987

Source: Slate

text.headline: Trump Tries, Fails to Meet Gorbachev
text.text:
Donald Trump attempts to meet with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, reportedly to sell him on his nuclear plan. This meeting never happened. At this time, Trump also began proclaiming his presidential ambitions and taking out newspaper advertisements harshly criticizing US foreign policy.

Source: Quartz

media.caption:
Reagan and President-elect Bush meeting with Gorbachev on Governors Island,
New York City, December 7, 1988
media.credit: White House Photographic Office - National Archives Identifier 198595

text.headline: Trump Taj Mahal Declares Bankruptcy
text.text:
Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City files for bankruptcy. After one year of operation, casino was nearly $3 billion in debt, and Trump had nearly $900 million in personal liabilities. It is Trump's first of what will be 6 bankruptcy filings.

Source: New York Times Source: Politifact

media.caption: Entrance to the Trump Taj Mahal, Atlantic City, New Jersey

text.headline: Trump’s Fourth Bankruptcy
text.text:
Trump files for bankruptcy on his Plaza Hotel, having accumulated more than $550 million in debt. It is Trump’s fourth bankruptcy filing.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Trump’s Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, New York City

text.headline: Trump’s Second Major Bankruptcy
text.text:
Another Trump casino, Trump’s Castle, files for bankruptcy, marking the second bankruptcy filing for Trump.

Source: Politifact

media.caption: Trumps Castle, 1993

text.headline: Trump’s Third Major Bankruptcy
text.text:
Trump Plaza and Casino in Atlantic City files for bankruptcy, having racked up $250 million in debt. It is Trump’s third bankruptcy filing.

Source: Philadelphia

media.caption: The Trump Plaza in Atlantic City, New Jersey

text.headline: Trump Applies for Trademark in Russia
text.text:
Trump applies for and receives a trademark in Russia for Trump Tower.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Records showing Trump's multiple trademarks in Russia

text.headline: Trump Plans $250 Million Moscow Project
text.text:
Trump announces plans to invest $250 million into building two luxury residential towers in Moscow. Ultimately, these buildings were not constructed.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Donald Trump at his Florida-based Mar-a-Lago resort in May 1996

text.headline: Trump Touts Statue Donated by Russia
text.text:
Trump attempts to erect a giant bronze statue of Christopher Columbus donated by the Russian government at his West Side Yards development on the Hudson River, a seventy-five-acre tract called Riverside South. The statute was six feet taller than the Statue of Liberty.

Source: The New Yorker

media.url: “The mayor of Moscow has written a letter to Rudy Giuliani stating that they would like to make a gift of this great work by [Russian artist] Zurab [Tsereteli]. It would be my honor if we could work it out with the City of New York. I am absolutely favorably disposed toward it.”
media.caption: Donald Trump, May 1997
media.credit: Mark Singer, The New Yorker, May 19, 1997

text.headline: Sater Joins Bayrock
text.text:
Felix Sater joined real estate firm Bayrock in 1999. The company pursued business with Trump and had offices in Trump Tower. As of 2016, a former Bayrock executive alleged the company received “unexplained” financing from Russia and Kazakhstan, including financing from a firm used by Russians “in favor with” Putin.

Source: Politico

media.caption: Felix Sater
media.credit: Getty Images, Peter Burka (Flickr). Design: Holly Warfield

text.headline: Tillerson Meets Putin, Strike Deal
text.text:
Rex Tillerson meets Putin in 1999 on the Sakhalin island in Russia's Far East, when Exxon struck a deal with Russian state-owned oil giant Rosneft. The two men have met a number of times since then, as Tillerson continued building a relationship with Putin through his business interests in Russia.

Source: Business Insider

media.caption: Putin and Tillerson meet outside Moscow, April 16, 2012

text.headline: Putin Takes Office
text.text:
Vladimir Putin takes office as Russian president.

Source: BBC News

media.caption: Putin at his first inauguration as president of Russia on May 7, 2000

text.headline: Russians Buy Trump Real Estate
text.text:
Throughout the 2000s, records show Russians were buying millions of dollars of Trump-branded real estate in the U.S., according to property records reviewed by the FT. The Trump Organization said it did not believe Russians spent more money on Trump ventures than those from other regions. Russian real estate broker Ilya Reznik told the FT that Russian could be heard everywhere in the Trump properties on the Florida coast.

Source: Financial Times

media.caption:
From left, the Trump Royale, the Trump Palace and the Trump International Beach
Resort in Sunny Isles Beach, Florida.

text.headline: Trump’s Fifth Bankruptcy
text.text:
Trump Hotels and Casinos Resorts files for bankruptcy, when Trump's casinos had accrued an estimated $1.8 billion in debt. Trump Taj Mahal was among the Trump properties that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2004. It is Trump's fifth bankruptcy filing.

Source: Politifact

media.caption: Trump Taj Mahal, Atlantic City, NJ

text.headline: Manafort Promotes Putin in Ukraine
text.text:
From 2005-2009, Paul Manafort received $10 million annually from Russian billionaire and aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska, a close Putin ally, in exchange for investment strategies and lobbying services on behalf of growing pro-Putin Russian parties in Ukraine.

Manfort has confirmed he worked for Deripaska, running the services through a company he registered as LOAV Ltd., instead of his consulting firm Davis Manafort. Deripaska described the nature of their business as investment consulting services now related to legal claims, however. There was a 2014 bankruptcy suit in the Cayman Islands between the two parties related to a $19 million investment in Ukrainian TV company Black Sea Cable. Through early 2016, Deripaska accused Manafort of fraud and alleged that Manafort took the money and stopped responding to communications.

Source: Associated Press

text.headline: Trump Gives Moscow Project to Bayrock
text.text:
Donald Trump gives Felix Sater and Bayrock an exclusive deal to develop a project in Russia.

Source: Forbes

text.headline: Trump and Sater Travel Together
text.text:
Trump and Felix Sater traveled extensively together and were photographed and interviewed in Denver and Loveland, Colorado, Phoenix, Fort Lauderdale, and New York.  

Source: The Daily Beast

text.headline: Trump Applies for Russian Trademarks
text.text:
From 2006-2008, Trump applies for several trademarks in Russia. These include: Trump, Trump Tower, Trump International Hotel and Tower, and Trump Home.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Kids and Sater Visit Moscow
text.text:
Felix Sater, Donald Jr. and Ivanka stayed at the historic Hotel National Moscow opposite the Kremlin in 2006, meeting several potential hotel partners. While Sater says that Donald Trump asked him to show his children around the city, Alan Garten, General Counsel of the Trump Organization, claims that it was a coincidence they were all there at the same time.

Source: New York Times
Source: Forbes

media.caption: Hotel National Moscow
media.credit: Yuri Kadobnov, Agence France-Presse, Getty Images

text.headline: Sater Describes Ties To Trump Deals
text.text:
Felix Sater says he’s dealing directly with Donald Trump and his family in a dispute, as described in a June 2007 email chain between Felix Sater, Trump Organization executives (including Donald Jr. and Ivanka), Bayrock executives, and Sapir Organization executives. Sapir is a “key Trump development partner” owned by then-billionaire and Russian immigrant Tamir Sapir.

Source: Forbes

media.url: “Donald Jr. and sr [sic] are calling me to talk about us eating it. I called Ivanka and told her I was pissed about Donald throwing me under the bus to Sapir. So now the billionairs [sic] can work it out.”
media.caption: Email from Felix Sater in June 2007

text.headline: Sater Secures Russian Investors for Trump
text.text:
In a 2007 deposition, Bayrock executive Felix Sater testifies he has identified Russian investors for the Trump Tower Moscow project.

Source: Washington Post

media.url: “[I would] pop my head into Mr. Trump’s office and tell him, you know, ‘Moving forward on the Moscow deal.’ And he would say, ‘ All right.’”
media.caption: Felix Sater in a 2007 deposition

text.headline: Trump Claims Ignorance on Bayrock Ownership
text.text:
Trump is deposed in a lawsuit two days after a New York Times background piece about Felix Sater and states that “Bayrock represented to me that he [Sater] was not a principal--[that] he's an employee.” In a later deposition Trump states, “I don't know who owns Bayrock.”

Source: Forbes

text.headline: Trump Discusses Building in Moscow
text.text:
In a deposition in 2007, Donald Trump declares,“we will be in Moscow at some point” while touting Russian business prospects. He discussed a deal for a Moscow-based Trump International Hotel and Tower that Bayrock had lined up with Russian investors.

Source: New York Times

media.url: “It would be a nonexclusive deal, so it would not have precluded me from doing other deals in Moscow, which was very important to me.”
media.caption: Donald Trump in a deposition, 2007

text.headline: Trump Gives Moscow Project to Bayrock
text.text:
With repeated bankruptcies limiting his access to capital, Donald Trump joins forces with New York developer Bayrock after being approached by Russian mob-connected Felix Sater. Bayrock’s founder is former Soviet Tevfik Arif. Trump said that most of his dealings with Bayrock were through Arif, and that his son Donald and his daughter Ivanka were playing active roles in managing the project.

In 1998, Sater avoided indictment for his involvement in a money laundering scheme by cooperating with authorities against Russian organized crime.

Source: New York Times
Source: Financial Times

media.caption: Donald Trump, Tevfik Arif and Felix Sater at the Trump SoHo

text.headline: Trump Overlooks Sater's Felonies
text.text:
Trump SoHo files an offering plan to sell apartments. The offering plan states that no one within Bayrock, the organization Trump is affiliated with for this project, has a prior felony conviction. However, Bayrock principal Felix Sater has multiple convictions.

Source: Forbes

media.caption: Email from Felix Sater in June 2007

text.headline: Trump Says Putin Is “Doing a Great Job”
text.text:
Donald Trump praises Putin on CNN's Larry King Live show, and says the Russian president is “doing a great job. . . . rebuilding Russia period.”

Source: CNN

media.caption: Trump with Larry King in a 1999 interview

text.headline: Trump Vodka Debuts in Moscow
text.text:
Trump Super Premium Vodka was presented at the Millionaire’s Fair in Moscow. The vodka was sold in Russia through 2009.

Source: New York Times
Source: Bloomberg

media.caption: Trump Vodka on display at the Millionaire Fair in Moscow in November 2007

text.headline: Manafort Partners With Ukrainian Tycoon
text.text:
In 2008, Paul Manafort partnered with Ukrainian energy tycoon Dmitry Firtash to develop Bulgari Tower, a 65-story Manhattan luxury apartment building, on the site of the Drake Hotel. The project fell through due to the economic recession, however.

Initially, the pair met in the early 2000s when Manafort was a political consultant for Ukraine president Viktor Yanukovych, whom Firtash supported.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Sater Confirms Bayrock Ownership
text.text:
Felix Sater was a real estate development partner with Trump through his role as a Bayrock principal. A 2008 e-mail from Sater states, “I am starting to get hyper sensitive to being involved as [a Bayrock] principal directly.” Sater was concerned banks would default on Bayrock projects in light of his association as a principal due to his criminal background.

The publication by Bayrock’s attorney of his status as a principal to investors during this period spurred him to plan a family trust that gave him an option to later purchase 30 percent of Bayrock.

Source: Forbes
Source: Email from Sater published by Forbes

media.url: “On Thursday Julius told iStar that I have a large economic interest in Bayrock....He then proceed [sic] to tell me to resign quickly and do the family trust thing on Monday the latest...”
media.caption: Email From Felix Sater in January 2008 about his status as Bayrock principal

text.headline: Sater Describes One-on-One Trump Meetings
text.text:
In a sworn deposition in 2008, Russian-born Felix Sater testifies he would pitch business ideas to Trump “just me and him” and his team “on a constant basis.”

Source: Forbes

text.headline: Sater Talks Plans to Build in Moscow
text.text:
In a 2008 deposition, Felix Sater stated that he told investors he would help build Trump Towers in the US and across the former Soviet bloc. “I can build a Trump Tower, because of my relationship with Trump,” he said. Trump gave Sater the green light to explore projects in Moscow and the US.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Jr. Talks Plans to Build in Russia
text.text:
At a “Real Estate in Russia” conference, Donald Trump, Jr. states the Trump Organization plans to build in Moscow, St. Petersburg, and Sochi.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Jr. Talks Russian Investors
text.text:
“And in terms of high-end product influx into the US, Russians make up a pretty disproportionate cross-section of a lot of our assets; say in Dubai, and certainly with our project in SoHo and anywhere in New York. We see a lot of money pouring in from Russia. There’s indeed a lot of money coming for new-builds and resale reflecting a trend in the Russian economy and, of course, the weak dollar versus the ruble,” Donald Trump, Jr. says at a conference.

Source: eTurbo News

text.headline: Trump Pitches Russian Reality TV Show
text.text:
Trump tries and fails to start reality TV show in St. Petersburg starring a Russian mixed martial arts fighter.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump: Putin ‘Much Better’ Than Bush
text.text:
In an interview with Russian-language magazine Chayka, Trump praises Putin while debuting a New York City condominium project catering in part to Russian buyers. “...[Putin] does his job well. Much better than our [President George W.] Bush,” Trump says.

Source: Washington Post

media.url: "By the way, I really like Vladi­mir Putin. . . . I respect him. He does his job well."
media.caption: Donald Trump to Chayka

text.headline: Trump Sells Mansion to Russian Oligarch
text.text:
During the summer of 2008, Trump makes significant money when he sells a mansion in Palm Beach for $95 million to Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev. Trump had purchased the home at a bankruptcy auction less than four years earlier for $41.4 million. At the time, the sale to Rybolovlev is regarded as the most expensive residential property sale in U.S. history.

Source: Washington Post

media.caption: Deed for the sale of Trump's Florida mansion to Dmitry Rybolovlev

text.headline: Allegation that Manafort Laundered $750K
text.text:
Ukrainian journalist and lawmaker Serhiy Leshchenko produces documents allegedly showing Paul Manafort used offshore accounts in 2009 to launder payments from Russian-backed, ex-Ukraine President Viktor Yanukovych’s Party of Regions totaling $750,000. The offshore accounts were located in Belize and Kyrgyzstan.

Leshchenko released a copy of an invoice on letterhead from Manafort’s Alexandria, VA-based consulting company in the amount of $750,000 for the sale of 501 computers to a Belize-based company. The invoice, dated Oct. 14, 2009, matches an identical amount made on the same day in the Party of Regions “black ledger” next to Manafort’s name. Leshchenko alleges that Manafort falsified the invoice to legitimize the $750,000 payment to himself.

Manafort previously denied receiving millions in secret payments from the Party of Regions, for whom he worked for nearly a decade. Such payments were detailed in a previously disclosed “black ledger” slush fund belonging to the party.

Source: Washington Post

media.caption: Serhiy Leshchenko holding pages allegedly showing payments to Paul Manafort, August 2016

text.headline: Trump Files 6th Bankruptcy
text.text:
Trump Entertainment Resorts files for bankruptcy after missing a $53.1 million bond interest payment in December 2008. It is Trump's sixth bankruptcy filing.

Source: CNN
Source: Politifact

text.headline: Trump Tied to Russian Real Estate Clients
text.text:
Belarus-American Sergei Millian, head of the Russian-American Chamber of Commerce and a real estate agent in Florida claims to have known Trump since 2007. The Russian-American Chamber of Commerce said in 2009 it had signed formal agreements with The Trump Organization to service Russian real estate clients, but the Trump Organization denied that Trump had any such relationship with Millian. As late as 2016, Millian told a Russian media outlet that he had been in contact with Trump and his aides.

Source: RIA - Russia
Source: Financial Times

media.url: “Our common acquaintances engaged in the organization of his trip to Russia in the “Millionaire Fair” in 2007. Then Trump invited me as the head of the Russian- American Chamber of Commerce (RACC) on horse races “Gulf Stream” in Miami. Later we met in his office in New York, where he introduced me to his right hand [Trump lawyer] Michael Cohen. . . . Then to me he was signed to a contract for the promotion in Russia and the CIS one of the real estate projects. You could say I was their exclusive broker. Then, in 2007-2008, the Russians bought dozens of apartments in buildings Trump in the US.”
media.caption: Sergei Millian

text.headline: Sater Works for Trump
text.text:
Around 2010, Felix Sater becomes a “Senior Advisor to Donald Trump” and is given an email address, business cards, and an office with the Trump Organization.

Source: Forbes Source: Politico

media.caption:
The phone number listed on Felix Sater's Trump Organization business card
previously belonged to a lawyer in Trump's general counsel's office.
media.credit: Photo: Shutterstock, Design: Nick DeSantis, Forbes

text.headline: Russia, Kazakhstan Finance Trump Soho
text.text:
Trump settles Soho lawsuit agreeing to refund 90% of deposits. A separate lawsuit claimed that Trump SoHo was developed with the undisclosed involvement of convicted felons and financing from questionable sources in Russia and Kazakhstan.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: The Trump family in 2010 at Trump SoHo ribbon-cutting ceremony

text.headline: Tillerson Signs Deal with Russia
text.text:
Rex Tillerson signs another deal with Rosneft for a lucrative $3.2 billion oil deal that would give Exxon permission to develop offshore oil fields in the Russian Arctic in exchange for Rosneft getting stakes in a number of Exxon's US-based projects.

Source: Business Insider

media.caption:
Vladimir Putin, 5th left, seen during his meeting with U.S. oil business top
executives in Washington, Friday, Sept. 16, 2005. Tillerson is first from the left.

text.headline: Putin's Third Inauguration
text.text:
Vladimir Putin begins his second nonconsecutive term as the president of Russia and is inaugurated for the third time.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn and Kislyak’s First Meeting
text.text:
Defense Intelligence Agency Director Michael Flynn meets Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Sergey Kislyak for the first time while on a trip to Moscow. Kislyak helped plan the trip.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn Meets With Russian Intelligence Leaders
text.text:
In 2013, Michael Flynn traveled to Russia to build a relationship with members of Russia’s intelligence agency, G.R.U. The trip earned him criticism by the American intelligence community. Following this trip Flynn hoped to invite G.R.U. members to the U.S., but was advised against it. During this period, Russia had annexed Crimea and there was fighting between Russian and Ukraine troops.

Source: The New Yorker

text.headline: Tillerson Awarded Russian 'Friendship' Medal
text.text:
Rex Tillerson was honored by Russia with the "Order of Friendship" award following deals signed between Exxon and Russian-owned oil company Rosneft. The award was established in 1994 by then-president Boris Yeltsin and has been awarded to various Americans.

Source: Washington Post
Source: NY Daily News

text.headline: Trump Deals in Moscow
text.text:
Trump reaches deal with Aras Agalarov, an oligarch serving as a Putin liaison, to build a Trump Tower in Moscow. During the same trip, Trump received payment from Agalarov and other investors for their part in the Miss Universe pageant. Trump would later brag that “almost all of the oligarchs were in the room.”

Source: Washington Post

media.caption:
From left, Donald Trump, Aras Agalarov, and Emin Agalarov walk the red carpet at
the Miss Universe pageant competition in Moscow in November 2013

text.headline: Trump Hints at Trump Tower Moscow
text.text:
Trump tweets to Russian billionaire Aras Agalarov about the prior weekend at the Miss Universe events in Moscow and hints at Trump Tower in Moscow.

Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump: “I know the Russians Very Well”
text.text:
Discussing the Sochi Olympics with David Letterman on his show, Trump says, “I've done a lot of business with the Russians. I know the Russians very well.”

Source: North Coast Voices

media.caption: Donald Trump on David Letterman, October 17, 2013

text.headline: Trump Plans Miss Universe in Moscow
text.text:
In anticipation of attending the Miss Universe Pageant, which he owns, Trump tweets: “Do you think Putin will be going to The Miss Universe Pageant in November in Moscow — if so, will he become my new best friend?” While at the pageant, Trump says, “I have plans for the establishment of business in Russia. Now, I am in talks with several Russian companies to establish this skyscraper.”

Source: Moyers and Company

text.headline: Exxon Increases Russian Holdings
text.text:
In a deal led by Rex Tillerson, Exxon boosts its Russian holdings to 63.7 million acres from 11.4 million. By way of comparison, during this period Exxon held rights to 14.6 million acres in the U.S., which was at that time its largest exploration prospect.

Source: Bloomberg

media.caption: Rex Tillerson accepts Russia's Order of Friendship medal from Vladimir Putin in 2013

text.headline: Obama Fires Flynn
text.text:
It is announced that Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn will be no longer be head of the Defense Intelligence Agency beginning Summer 2014.

Source: Washington Post

media.caption: Michael Flynn

text.headline: Russia Invades Crimea
text.text:
Breaking international law, Putin takes the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine by force, secures the route to export oil by sea, and takes control of the port where the Black Sea Naval Fleet is based.

Source: Time

media.caption: Unidentified gunmen on patrol at Simferopol International Airport on Feb. 28, 2014

text.headline: Russians Fund Trump Golf Courses
text.text:
During a golf outing with sports writer James Dodson at the Trump National Golf Club in Charlotte, NC, in 2014, Eric Trump said, “Well, we don’t rely on American banks [to fund Trump golf courses]. We have all the funding we need out of Russia.”

Source: Fox News

media.caption: Eric Trump at the Eric Trump Golf Tournament at Trump National Golf Club Westchester in Briarcliff Manor, New York, on Sept. 15, 2014

text.headline: Trump Praises Putin
text.text:
On the same day President Obama signs an executive order imposing sanctions on Russia for its unlawful annexation of Crimea, Trump praises Putin during a speech before the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC). “You know, I was in Moscow a couple of months ago. I own the Miss Universe Pageant and they treated me so great. Putin even sent me a present, a beautiful present,” he said.

Source: U.S. News and World Report
Source: Moyers and Company

media.caption: Trump speaking at CPAC, March 6, 2014

text.headline: Trump: Putin Does Not Respect U.S.
text.text:
At a National Press Club luncheon where he was a guest of honor, Trump was asked what he would do if dealing with Putin.

He said, “Well, in negotiation, the primary thing that you have to do is to get the other side to respect you. And President Putin does not respect, or like, President Obama. So you have a problem. I’m not sure that’s a problem that's easily solvable, there’s a dislike. But Russia does not respect our country any longer. They see that we’ve been greatly weakened both militarily and otherwise. And he certainly does not respect President Obama. So, what I would do would be, as an example, I own the Miss Universe. I was in Russia, I was in Moscow recently, and I spoke indirectly and directly with President Putin, who could not have been nicer. And we had a tremendous success. The show was live from Moscow and we had a tremendous success there. And it was amazing. But to do well, you have to get the other side to respect you, and he does not respect our president, which is very sad.”

Source: National Press Club
Source: Financial Times

media.caption: Trump speaking at National Press Club, May 27, 2014

text.headline: Alleged Money Laundering on Trump Projects
text.text:
A New York court unseals a lawsuit filed on behalf of the state of New York against Bayrock, Felix Sater and others. It alleges that the group sought to evade taxation and hide its true foreign ownership by laundering as much as $250 million in profits on Trump projects.

The attorneys behind the suit tell Forbes that new information leads them to believe that Trump participated in the schemes and lied about his involvement.

Source: Forbes

media.caption: The filed complaint in People of New York v. Bayrock

text.headline: Flynn Paid by Russian Cargo Airline
text.text:
Michael Flynn received payment for unknown services from the Russia-based Volga-Dnepr Airlines, which had been suspended as a UN-approved vendor after an investigation revealed they had bribed officials.

Source: Congressional Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

text.headline: Flynn Paid by Russian Media Company RT
text.text:
A letter released by congressional investigators in March 2017 shows that Michael Flynn received previously undisclosed payments from various companies linked to Russian security interests in 2015. Among these companies was state-funded media company Russia Today (“RT"), a cybersecurity firm, and a cargo airline implicated in a UN bribery scheme. Flynn spoke at the RT Gala in Moscow around Dec. 10, 2015.

Source: Congressional Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

text.headline: Flynn Paid by Top Russian Cybersecurity Firm
text.text:
Michael Flynn received a $11,250 payment from Kaspersky Government Security Solutions, a Russia-based subsidiary of Kaspersky labs. At the time, the firm had been described as “the foremost researcher uncovering Western spyware for the past several years."

Source: Congressional Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

text.headline: Manafort Family Texts About Ukraine
text.text:
A trove of 300,000 text messages released by an anonymous hacker showed that Paul Manafort's daughters, Jessica and Andrea, were concerned about the violence and illegality of Paul Manafort's Russian-supported politicking in Ukraine.

In March of 2015, Andrea texted Jessica, “You know he had people killed in Ukraine? Knowingly.” In another message, Andrea said “Don't fool yourself, that money we have is blood money.” Andrea also texted someone else that her father's work and payment in Ukraine was “legally questionable.”

Source: New York Daily News

media.url: "He has no moral or legal compass"
media.caption: Andrea Manafort in a text message about her father, Paul Manafort

text.headline: Michael Flynn Dines with Putin
text.text:
Michael Flynn attends a dinner honoring the Kremlin-aligned English language media company RT, where he sits near Putin. Flynn made a paid appearance on the network. Green Party presidential nominee Jill Stein attended the dinner as well and sat three seats to Putin’s left.

Source: Washington Post
Source: Washington Post

media.caption: Vladimir Putin dining with Michael Flynn, December 10, 2015
media.credit: Mikhail Klimentyev Sputnik, Kremlin pool photo via AP; NBC News

text.headline: NRA Meets Putin's Deputy Prime Minister
text.text:
The National Rifle Association, one of Donald Trump’s largest allies, sent a 30-person delegation to Russia to meet with Putin’s Deputy Prime Minister, Dmitry Rogozin, who serves as head of Russia’s defense industry. The NRA claims that Rogozin, also chairman of the Russian Shooting Federation, provided a tour of the Federation's offices and they discussed a shooting tournament. This trip occurred the same week as Michael Flynn’s dinner with Putin.

Rogozin is well-known in Russia and the U.S. as the “radical” former leader of the ultra-right Rodina (“Motherland” in Russian) Party. In March 2014, the U.S. sanctioned him in retaliation for the invasion of Crimea and eastern Ukraine.

Source: The Daily Beast
Source: Facebook Page of PravoNaOruzie

media.caption: Picture of the NRA's visit to Russia (See source link for full text)

text.headline: Putin Praises Trump
text.text:
Putin praises Trump to ABC News, calling him “talented” and “colorful.” He also said that Trump was “absolutely the leader in the American presidential race."

Putin further acknowledged that Russia welcomed relations between Russia and the U.S. under Trump.

“How can Russia not welcome that? We welcome that," Putin said.

Source: ABC News

media.credit: New York Daily News on YouTube

text.headline: Trump Basks In Putin’s Praise
text.text:
Before any ballots are cast in the primary election, Trump declares praise he has received from Putin is a “great honor” and rejects allegations that Putin had killed journalists and other political opponents.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Casino Fined by Treasury
text.text:
The US Treasury fines Trump Taj Mahal $10 million, the largest penalty ever against a casino, for “significant, long standing anti-money laundering violations.”

Source: U.S. Department of the Treasury

text.headline: Trump Knows Putin “Very Well”
text.text:
Trump says, during the fourth GOP presidential debate, that he got to know Putin when they were on 60 Minutes together. 

Source: Moyers and Company
Source: NBC News

media.caption: President Trump during the 4th Republican Presidential Debate, November 10, 2015

text.headline: Trump Praises Putin
text.text:
Donald Trump tells Bill O'Reilly of Fox News: “I will tell you in terms of leadership [Putin] is getting an ‘A’ and our president is not doing so well.”

Source: CBS News

text.headline: Report of Flynn's Intercepted Conversations
text.text:
Following Putin's statement that he won't retaliate against the U.S. for placing sanctions on Russia, U.S. intelligence analysts uncover communications between Michael Flynn and Sergey Kislyak upon reviewing intercepted communications.

Source: The Hill

text.headline: Carter Page Critizes U.S. Policy
text.text:
Two weeks before the Republican National Convention, Trump foreign policy adviser Carter Page travels to Moscow and once again criticizes U.S. policy. Speaking at a commencement address for the New Economic School, an institution funded in part by major Russian oligarchs close to Putin, Page asserts that “Washington and other West capitals” had impeded progress in Russia “through their often hypocritical focus on ideas such as democratization, inequality, corruption and regime change.”

Source: Reuters

media.caption: Carter Page speaks at New Economic School in Moscow on July 8, 2016

text.headline: Carter Page Returns to Moscow
text.text:
Previous Trump foreign policy adviser Carter Page returns to Moscow, telling Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti he will meet with "business leaders and thought leaders." Kremlin spokesperson Dmitri S. Peskov, the Kremlin’s spokesman, told news agency Interfax that government leaders had no plans to meet with Page and that they had never had any contact with him. Russia’s deputy foreign minister, Sergei Ryabkov, said his department had no plans to meet with Page.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: GOP Platform Change Facts Confirmed
text.text:
NPR confirms the Trump campaign provided little input into the GOP platform prior to the Republican National Convention, except when it came to the party’s stance on Ukraine.

Source: NPR

media.caption:
One of the “little green men” - Russian soldiers without insignia spearheading
the 2014 annexation of Crimea

text.headline: Congress Concerned About Election Interference
text.text:
Sen. Dianne Feinstein, vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, and Rep. Adam Schiff, ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee, release a joint statement about Russia's interference in the election.

“Based on briefings we have received, we have concluded that the Russian intelligence agencies are making a serious and concerted effort to influence the U.S. election.
At the least, this effort is intended to sow doubt about the security of our election and may well be intended to influence the outcomes of the election—we can see no other rationale for the behavior of the Russians.
We believe that orders for the Russian intelligence agencies to conduct such actions could come only from very senior levels of the Russian government.
We call on President Putin to immediately order a halt to this activity. Americans will not stand for any foreign government trying to influence our election. We hope all Americans will stand together and reject the Russian effort.”
Source: Yahoo News
Source: Website of Senator Feinstein

text.headline: Conway Also Disclaims Page
text.text:
Kellyanne Conway told CNN’s Jake Tapper that Carter Page is “certainly not part of the campaign that I'm running, meaning we don't have him — we have a number of people, fabulous people, men and women, as part of our national security and foreign policy team. And he's not among them at Trump Tower." With respect to Carter Page's contact with the Kremlin she said, “If he's doing that, he's certainly not doing it with the permission or knowledge of the campaign, the activities that you described. . . . He is certainly not authorized to do that.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Interview of Kellyanne Conway on CNN, September 25, 2016

text.headline: FISA Warrant for Trump Campaign's Activities in Russia
text.text:
A “FISA warrant was granted in connection with the investigation of suspected activity between the server [at Trump Tower] and two banks, SVB Bank and [Russia’s] Alfa Bank.”

Intelligence community sources said the warrant was sought because actionable intelligence provided by foreign agencies could not properly be examined without a warrant by U.S. intelligence. The intelligence concerns “U.S. Persons” who come under the remit of the FBI and not the CIA. Should a counter-intelligence investigation lead to criminal prosecutions, sources say, the Justice Department is concerned that the chain of evidence have a basis in a clear warrant. It is believed in the intelligence community that the warrant covers any “U.S. person” connected to this investigation, and thus covers Donald Trump and at least three additional men associated with his campaign.

Source: Heat Street

media.caption: FISA warrant rumors began circulating shortly before it was confirmed

text.headline: Five Unsecured Calls by Flynn to Kislyak
text.text:
On the same day that President Obama announces sanctions against Russia in retaliation for its interference in the 2016 election, national security adviser- designate Lt. Gen. Flynn places five phone calls to the Russian ambassador. These calls were apparently on unsecured lines, and monitored by U.S. intelligence agencies.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

media.caption: Tweet by Michael McFaul

text.headline: Flynn and Russian Ambassador Discuss Sanctions
text.text:
Michael Flynn discusses sanctions with Sergey Kislyak in a phone call, according to officials who have seen a transcript of the wiretapped conversation.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Report that Michael Flynn discussed sanctions with Sergey Kislyak

text.headline: Flynn Appointed National Security Adviser
text.text:
President-Elect Trump appoints Michael Flynn as National Security Advisor.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn Calls Russian Ambassador
text.text:
Following the death of the Russian ambassador to Turkey, Michael Flynn called Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Sergey Kislyak to express condolences.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn Endorses Trump
text.text:
Michael Flynn gives a speech endorsing Trump at the Republican National Convention.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn is Advising Trump Campaign
text.text:
Reuters reports that Michael Flynn is advising the Trump campaign.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn Requests Clearance for Son
text.text:
Vice President-elect Mike Pence denied that Michael Flynn's son, Michael G. Flynn, has a role with the presidential transition. Later that day, it was revealed that Michael Flynn requested security clearance for his son to assist with the transition. In response to this news, Pence says that Flynn Jr. was helping his father with scheduling.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn texts Russian Ambassador
text.text:
Michael Flynn texts Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak to wish him a merry Christmas and to express condolences for a plane crash.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

media.caption: Michael Flynn

text.headline: Giuliani Says Trump Has “Surprises”
text.text:
Two weeks before the presidential election, Former New York City Mayor and Trump adviser Rudy Giuliani appears on “Fox and Friends,” and states “We’ve got a couple of surprises left. . . . I’d call them surprises in the way that we’re going to campaign to get our message out there — maybe in a little bit of different way.”

Source: The Hill

text.headline: Intelligence Looks at Page, Trump, and Russians
text.text:
Multiple sources briefed on the issue report that U.S. intelligence officials are investigating whether Carter Page, one of Trump's foreign policy advisers, established private lines of communications with senior Russian officials, including discussions about lifting U.S. sanctions if Trump becomes president.

Source: Yahoo News

media.url: “Some of those briefed were 'taken aback' when they learned about Page’s contacts in Moscow, viewing them as a possible back channel to the Russians that could undercut U.S. foreign policy, said a congressional source familiar with the briefings but who asked for anonymity due to the sensitivity of the subject. The source added that U.S. officials in the briefings indicated that intelligence reports about the adviser’s talks with senior Russian officials close to President Vladimir Putin were being ‘actively monitored and investigated.’”

text.headline: Internet Domain Reserved by Sater for Trump
text.text:
Forbes uncovers over 100 Internet domain names that lead back to Felix Sater. One of those domain names seems to be for Trump (DealsByTrump.com). Sater's lawyer denies any connection.

Source: Forbes

media.caption: DealsByTrump.com is one domain names traced to Felix Sater in Sept. 2016
media.credit: Photo: Mark Von Holden, WireImage. Design: Nick DeSantis, Forbes staff

text.headline: Kushner Meets Putin Tied Russian Bank
text.text:
Jared Kusher, Trump’s son-in-law, Senior White House Adviser, and head of Kushner Companies, meets with executives of Russian state-run development bank Vnesheconombank (VEB) in late 2016.

U.S. officials allege that Kushner first met with former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn and Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, and then met with VEB chairman Sergei Gorkov in December 2016 during a bank roadshow. Gorkov was appointed head of the VEB by Russian president Vladimir Putin in early 2016 and is a decorated member of the Russian Federal Security Service. VEB, along with other Russian banks, has been under Western economic sanctions since 2014 concerning Russia’s annexation of part of Ukraine.

Kushner has agreed to testify before the U.S. Senate over suspected Russian interference in the presidential election.

Source: CNBC

media.caption: VEB Bank Chairman Sergei Gorkov in an undated photo

text.headline: Manafort Denies Trump Campaign’s Russia Ties
text.text:
When asked if there are any connections between the Trump campaign and Russia or its president, Paul Manafort tells ABC’s This Week: “No, there are not. And you know, there's no basis to it."

Source: USA Today
Source: ABC News

media.url: “It's absurd and there's no basis to it.”
media.caption: Paul Manafort interview with George Stephanopoulos, July 24, 2016

text.headline: Manafort Resigns
text.text:
Paul Manafort resigns from the Trump campaign as reports of his financial connections to Ukraine intensify. Manafort denied any wrongdoing and rejected the suggestion that he received “off the books” funds from his work in Ukraine.

Source: Washington Post

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Manafort Unaware of Investigation
text.text:
Former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort tells NBC News he is unaware of any FBI investigation into his alleged connections to Putin or interactions with the Russian government.

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Paul Manafort, New York City on June 9, 2016

text.headline: Manafort’s Financial Ukraine Connection
text.text:
A handwritten ledger reveals $12.7 M in payments from former Ukrainian President Victor Yanukovych’s pro-Russian political party from 2007 to 2012 to Trump campaign CEO Paul Manafort. According to investigators, these disbursements were “part of an illegal off-the-books system whose recipients also included election officials.”

Source: New York Times

media.caption:
A page from the “black ledger,” released by Ukraine’s National Anti-Corruption
Bureau.

text.headline: Obama Warns Trump About Flynn
text.text:
Trump met with Barack Obama days after the U.S. presidential election. During their meeting in the Oval Office, Obama warned Trump about Flynn's ties to Russia. Flynn was terminated from his position as head of military intelligence during the Obama administration; Trump would later appoint Flynn as head of national security.

Source: Los Angeles Times

media.caption: President Obama and Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Nov. 10, 2016

text.headline: Page and Sechin Discuss U.S. Sanctions
text.text:
During the same trip to Moscow where he addressed the New Economic School, Carter Page also met with Igor Sechin, former Russian deputy prime minister and current chairman of the Russian oil conglomerate Rosneft. Sechin was one of Russian officials and businessmen sanctioned over Russia's “illegitimate and unlawful actions in the Ukraine.” The Treasury announcement described Sechin as “utterly loyal to Vladimir Putin — a key component to his current standing.” At their meeting, Sechin raised the issue of the lifting of sanctions, the intelligence source claimed.

Source: Yahoo News
Source: Reuters

media.caption:
Rosneft CEO Igor Sechin with Vladimir Putin at a signing ceremony at the St.
Petersburg International Economic Forum 2014

text.headline: Page Denies Acting as Intermediary
text.text:
Carter Page described himself as “on leave” from being an informal foreign policy advisor to the Trump campaign and denied allegations that he was acting as a “go-between for the Trump campaign and Russian officials,” as alleged in a letter to the FBI by Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid.

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Letter from Senatory Harry Reid to FBI Director Comey, August 27, 2016

text.headline: Page is Informal Adviser, Says Trump Campaign
text.text:
After Carter Page criticized US foreign policy concerning Russia in a speech in Moscow, Trump Campaign spokesperson Hope Hicks told the Washington Post in a follow-up piece that Page was an “informal foreign policy adviser” who “does not speak for Mr. Trump or the campaign.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Carter Page in Moscow

text.headline: Page Meets with Diveykin
text.text:
U.S. intelligence receives reports Carter Page met with Igor Diveykin, a former Russian security official. Diveykin serves as deputy chief for internal policy and is believed by U.S. officials to have responsibility for the intelligence Russia collected regarding the U.S. election.

Source: Yahoo News

text.headline: Carter Page Named a Trump Foreign-Policy Adviser
text.text:
Donald Trump named Carter Page, an American investment banker whose business deals with Russia and its state-run gas company, as one of his foreign-policy advisers, after which Page's inbox filled up with positive notes from Russian contacts.

Source: Bloomberg

media.caption: Carter Page in Tbilisi, Georgia

text.headline: Putin Will Not Retaliate for U.S. Sanctions
text.text:
Putin says he will not retaliate against the U.S. sanctions imposed by Russia, one day after his press secretary and foreign minister promised retaliation in kind. An official statement from Putin was posted on the Kremlin’s Web site: “We will not create any problems for US diplomats. We will not expel anyone.”

Source: Kremilin Website
Source: New York Times
Source: New Yorker

media.url: “As it proceeds from international practice, Russia has reasons to respond in kind. Although we have the right to retaliate, we will not resort to irresponsible ‘kitchen’ diplomacy but will plan our further steps to restore Russian-US relations based on the policies of the Trump Administration.”

text.headline: Release of Russian Collected Information About Trump
text.text:
An unnamed former Western intelligence officer—who spent almost two decades on Russian intelligence matters and who now works with a US firm that gathers information on Russia for corporate clients—was assigned to research Trump’s dealings in Russia and elsewhere, according to the former spy and his associates in this American firm. This was for an opposition research project originally financed by a Republican client critical of Trump, later switched to a client allied with Democrats. He came across troubling information indicating connections between Trump and the Russian government. According to his sources, he says, “there was an established exchange of information between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin of mutual benefit.”

His first memo to the FBI stated: “[The] Russian regime has been cultivating, supporting and assisting TRUMP for at least 5 years. Aim, endorsed by PUTIN, has been to encourage splits and divisions in western alliance.” It maintained that Trump “and his inner circle have accepted a regular flow of intelligence from the Kremlin, including on his Democratic and other political rivals.” It claimed that Russian intelligence had “compromised” Trump during his visits to Moscow and could “blackmail him.” The former spy said FBI responded with “shock and horror.”

Source: Mother Jones

media.url: “The former spy says he concluded that the information he had collected on Trump was ‘sufficiently serious’ to share with the FBI.”

text.headline: Roger Stone and WikiLeaks
text.text:
Former Trump adviser Roger Stone claimed not to have advance warning of the WikiLeaks release of John Podestas, but also told NBC News, “I have back-channel communications with WikiLeaks” because he and founder Julian Assange have a “mutual friend.”  

Source: NBC News

media.caption: Roger Stone

text.headline: Russia Claims Regular Contact With Trump
text.text:
Multiple Russian government officials make public statements that they had regular contact with the Trump campaign throughout the election. Trump campaign spokesperson Hope Hicks tells the Associated Press, “It never happened. There was no communication between the campaign and any foreign entity during the campaign.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Trump and Hope Hicks in Muscatine, Iowa, Jan. 24, 2016

text.headline: Russia Promises Retaliation for Sanctions
text.text:
Russian response to Obama’s Dec. 29, 2016, sanctions announcement was immediate. The Russian government made clear that Putin would retaliate in kind. The sanctions caused thirty-five Russian diplomats to be expelled from the U.S. and two Russian compounds were closed.

Putin's press secretary, Dmitry Peskovto, said, “There is no doubt that Russia’s adequate and mirror response will make Washington officials feel very uncomfortable, as well.” Russian Foreign minister Sergey Larov proposed that Putin “announce thirty-one personnel of the U.S. Embassy in Moscow and four diplomats from the Consulate General in St. Petersburg persona non grata,” as well as the closure of two facilities used by American diplomats.

Source: The New Yorker

media.caption: Russian Embassy in the USA on Twitter

text.headline: Russia Sells Minority Stake in Rosneft
text.text:
The Russian government announces it will sell nearly 20 percent of state-run oil company, Rosneft, to Swiss commodity trading firm, Glencore, and the Qatar Investment Authority for approximately $11.3 Bil.  As of January 2017, the owners of Glencore were still unknown.

The deal suggests foreign investors are reconsidering U.S. sanctions against Russia following election of Trump. At the time, Trump was considering Exxon-Mobil Chairman Rex Tillerson for secretary of state. Tillerson had been critical of the sanctions.

Source: New York Times
Source: Reuters

media.url: “More than a month after Russia announced one of its biggest privatizations since the 1990s, selling a 19.5 percent stake in its giant oil company Rosneft, it still isn't possible to determine from public records the full identities of those who bought it.”

text.headline: Russian Ambassador at Trump Tower
text.text:
Michael Flynn and Jared Kushner reportedly met with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak for 20 minutes at Trump Tower in early December 2016.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Russian Government Directed Email Hack
text.text:
In a joint statement, the Department of Homeland Security and the Director of National Intelligence set forth their confidence and belief that the most senior officials of the Russian Government directed hacking of e-mails from U.S. persons and institutions, including from U.S. political organizations. 

Source: Homeland Security Website (archived content)

media.url: The U.S. Intelligence Community (USIC) is confident that the Russian Government directed the recent compromises of e-mails from US persons and institutions, including from US political organizations. The recent disclosures of alleged hacked e-mails on sites like DCLeaks.com and WikiLeaks and by the Guccifer 2.0 online persona are consistent with the methods and motivations of Russian-directed efforts. These thefts and disclosures are intended to interfere with the US election process.
media.caption: Department of Homeland Security and Director of National Intelligence

text.headline: Russian Involvement in Election Confirmed
text.text:
American intelligence agencies concluded with “high confidence” that Russia acted covertly in the latter stages of the presidential campaign to harm Hillary Clinton’s chances and promote Donald Trump, according to senior administration officials.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: News report about CIA confirmation that Russians interfered in the 2016 U.S. election.
media.credit: Reuters published by Straits Times on YouTube

text.headline: Russian Response to Election Results
text.text:
Russia’s Parliament applauded following announcement of Trump’s win by MP Vyacheslav Nikonov at the Russian Parliament. Nikonov said, “I congratulate all of you on this.” 

Source: The Independent (UK)

media.url: According to The Independent (UK), “State news agency RIA-Novosti and Russian website Interfax.com quoted Mr Nikonov, also chairman of the Education Committee, as saying: ‘Three minutes ago, Hillary Clinton acknowledged her defeat in the U.S. presidential elections and just seconds ago, Trump began his speech as president-elect. I congratulate all of you on this.’” News of Trump’s win “was almost drowned out by clapping and cheering in the State Duma.”

text.headline: Russian UN Ambassador Defends Trump
text.text:
Russian UN Ambassador Vitaly Churkin files a complaint with the UN over comments by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein for condemning Donald Trump and right-wing European politicians.

Source: CNN

text.headline: Sater's Contributions to Trump Campaign
text.text:
Felix Sater, a Russian-born and Mafia-linked businessman, contributed the maximum allowed to Donald Trump’s campaign during summer 2016 and claimed to take secret meetings in Trump Tower. A campaign spokesperson said at the time that they were unaware of Sater’s donations, but later reimbursed him when “Sater gave the campaign $5,520 in three donations in July, according to the campaign’s August FEC filing. Because the maximum allowed individual contribution is $5400, the campaign refunded the $120 difference.”

Source: Politico
Source: Forbes

media.caption: Sater gave the campaign $5,520 and was refunded the $120 difference
media.credit: Photo: Getty Images, Shutterstock. Design: Holly Warfield, Forbes staff

text.headline: Senator Requests Trump-Russia Investigation
text.text:
The Senate minority leader, Harry Reid, sends letter to FBI director, James B. Comey Jr., expressing concern that Russia was trying to influence the presidential election and requesting that the FBI open an investigation.

Source: New York Times
Source: New York Times

text.headline: Stone Communicates with DNC Hacker
text.text:
Former Trump campaign supervisor Roger Stone has a conversation with Russia-connected DNC hacker “Guccifer 2.0” via private message on Twitter. Stone would later deny this occurred, then would admit it, saying he had “completely forgotten” about the conversation.

U.S. Intelligence believes Guccifer 2.0 is “a cover identity” for Russian intelligence services.

Source: The Hill

media.caption: Roger Stone
media.credit: Carl Juste - Miami Herald - Getty Images

text.headline: Stone Foresees Podesta Hack
text.text:
Six days before Wikileaks releases emails that Russian hackers acquired from John Podesta’s email account, Trump’s informal adviser and surrogate, Roger Stone tweets: “Wednesday@HillaryClinton is done. #Wikileaks.” [sic]

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Support for Ukraine Removed from GOP Platform
text.text:
During the Republican National Convention, Trump’s campaign seeks a tweak to the GOP platform, softening a call for the U.S. to provide Ukraine with lethal defensive weapons in its ongoing fight with Russian-backed separatists.

The Trump campaign, at the time chaired by Paul Manafort, worked ahead of the 2016 Republican Convention on a plank of the 2016 Party Platform that gutted the GOP’s longstanding support for Ukrainians' popular resistance to Russia’s 2014 intervention.

Manfort worked for more than a decade as a lobbyist for Russian-backed former Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Tillerson Nominated for Secretary of State
text.text:
Rex Tillerson, chairman of Exxon Mobil, is nominated for Secretary of State. He is a recipient of Russia’s “Order of Friendship” Medal from Vladimir Putin in 2013, and is praised by Trump as “much more than a business executive” and a “world-class player.” Trump said Tillerson “knows many of the players” and did “massive deals in Russia” for Exxon.

Source: The Guaradian (UK)
Source: CNN

text.headline: Tillerson Nomination a “Gift” for Putin
text.text:
Former Russian Energy Minister Vladimir Milov told NBC News that the nomination of Rex Tillerson, someone seen as close to President Putin, would be financially and diplomatically advantageous for Putin.

Source: NBC News

text.headline: Trump Campaign Approves Page Trip to Moscow
text.text:
Prior to his Moscow travels in July 2016, Carter Page asked his supervisor, Trump Campaign Director of National Security J.D. Gordon, for permission to take the trip. Gordon advised against it. Page then obtained formal approval via email from then-campaign manager Corey Lewandowski and spokesperson Hope Hicks. A statement from Hicks stated Page was not representing the campaign in Moscow. The campaign fired Lewandowski on June 20, prior to the trip. The campaign would later distance itself from Page.

Source: Politico

text.headline: Trump Campaign Denies Russian Contacts
text.text:
Russia’s deputy foreign minister Sergei Ryabkov told Interfax news agency that the Russian government maintained "contacts" with Trump's “immediate entourage.” He also said, “We continue to do this and have been doing this work during the election campaign,” he said. The Russian foreign ministry later said there were no contacts with Trump's campaign staff, but rather with American politicians and supporters, and Trump spokesperson. Hope Hicks denied the campaign was aware of any contacts between campaign representatives and Russian officials prior to the election.

Source: New York Times

media.url: “We are not aware of any campaign representatives that were in touch with any foreign entities before yesterday, when Mr. Trump spoke with many world leaders,” Ms. Hicks, said. “Those discussions were congratulatory and forward looking.”

text.headline: Trump Campaign Disclaims Page Again
text.text:
Trump campaign rapid response director Steven Cheung tells ABC News that Carter Page “has no role” in the campaign. “We are not aware of any of his activities; past or present,” he said, using the same statement as that made the day before by Miller.

Source: USA Today

media.url: “We are not aware of any of his activities, past or present,”
media.caption: Steven Cheung's statement to ABC News, September 24, 2016

text.headline: Trump Campaign Disclaims Page's Role
text.text:
Trump campaign spokesperson Jason Miller tells Yahoo! News that Carter Page “has no role” in the campaign.

Source: USA Today

media.url: “We are not aware of any of his activities, past or present,”
media.caption: Jason Miller's statement to Yahoo! News, September 23, 2016

text.headline: Trump Campaign Meets Pro-Putin Ukrainian
text.text:
The New York Times and Politico report that Andrii Artemenko met with Trump campaign officials after he traveled to Cleveland for last summer’s Republican ational Convention. The Times adds that Artemenko says that “he saw in Mr. Trump an opportunity to advocate a plan for peace in Ukraine — and help advance his own political career.” (Artemenko would later deliver to the White House a peace proposal via Trump attorney Cohen, outlining a way to remove U.S. sanctions on Russia one week before Flynn’s resignation.)

Source: New York Magazine

media.caption: Ukrainian lawmaker Andrii Artemenko at his office in Kiev, Ukraine

text.headline: Trump Campaign Russian Contacts
text.text:
Phone records and intercepted calls show that members of Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and other Trump associates had repeated contacts with senior Russian intelligence and government officials in the year before the election, according to four current and former American officials.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Considers Flynn as VP
text.text:
Trump considers retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn as his vice-presidential running mate.

Source: Washington Post

media.caption: Photograph of Michael Flynn at the Defense Intelligence Agency

text.headline: Trump Defends Russia at Second Debate
text.text:
During the second presidential debate, Trump said during the discussion of hacking of Democratic Party systems, “Maybe there is no hacking but they always blame Russia and the reason is because they think they’re trying to tarnish me with Russia. I know about Russia, but I know nothing about the inner workings of Russia. I have no businesses, I have no loans from Russia.”

Source: New York Times
Source: Financial Times

media.caption: Donald Trump at the second presidential debate, October 9, 2016

text.headline: Trump Denies Meeting Putin
text.text:
During the third presidential debate, Trump says, “I don’t know Putin. I have no idea… I never met Putin. This is not my best friend.” Also during the debate he said, “I have nothing to do with Putin. I've never spoken to him.”

Source: The Independent (UK)

media.caption: Donald Trump on Russia and WikiLeaks during the final Presidential debate, October 19, 2016

text.headline: Trump Denies Relationship With Putin
text.text:
At a campaign rally in Walterboro, South Carolina, Trump denies having a relationship with Putin. 

Source: C-SPAN
Source: Moyers and Company

media.url: “I have no relationship with [Putin], other than he called me a genius.”
media.caption: Donald Trump at a campaign rally, Walterboro, South Carolina, February 17, 2016

text.headline: Trump Discusses Clinton Email Hack
text.text:
Trump says: "[Clinton] has no idea whether it is Russia, China or anybody else... Our country has no idea."

Source: NBC News

text.headline: Trump Dismisses CIA Report
text.text:
In response to reports that the CIA concluded Russia intervened in the election to help Trump win, the Trump transition team issued the following statement: “These are the same people that said Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. The election ended a long time ago in one of the biggest Electoral College victories in history. It’s now time to move on and ‘Make America Great Again.’”

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Disputes Russian Hack
text.text:
During the second presidential debate, Trump disclaims there was any DNC hack. He said, “I don't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC. [Hillary Clinton is] saying Russia, Russia, Russia, but I don't -- maybe it was. I mean, it could be Russia, but it could also be China. It could also be lots of other people. It also could be somebody sitting on their bed that weighs 400 pounds, OK?”

Source: NBC News

media.caption: Donald Trump on Russian hacking during the 1st Presidential Debate, October 9, 2016

text.headline: Trump hires Paul Manafort
text.text:
Trump hires Paul Manafort as manager of the campaign delegate-getting operation. Manafort then displaced Corey Lewandowski, the Trump campaign manager.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Magazine

media.caption: Paul Manafort
media.credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times

text.headline: Trump Invites Russia to Hack Clinton
text.text:
After WikiLeaks posts hacked emails from the DNC, Trump refuses to criticize — instead inviting Russia to hack his Democratic opponent; “Russia, if you’re listening, I hope you’re able to find the 30,000 emails that are missing,” he said referring to emails Hillary Clinton had deleted as personal while secretary of state.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times
Source: Yahoo News

text.headline: Trump: “Not Going to Renounce” Putin
text.text:
Trump on Putin: “A guy calls me a genius, and I'm going to renounce? I'm not going to renounce him.”

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Proposes Russia and USA Fight ISIS
text.text:
Trump says the US needs better ties with Russia to fight ISIS: “Wouldn't it be nice if we actually got along with people, wouldn't it be nice if we actually got along, as an example, with Russia?”

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

media.url: “If we could get Russia to help us get rid of ISIS — if we could actually be friendly with Russia — wouldn’t that be a good thing?” Mr. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, said. Repeating the question moments later, he won loud applause from the crowd: “If we could get along with Russia, wouldn’t that be a good thing, instead of a bad thing?”
media.caption: Donald Trump, speaking at a rally in Columbus, OH, on August 1, 2016

text.headline: Trump, Sessions and Kislyak Meet
text.text:
Jeff Sessions and Donald Trump met Sergey Kislyak in April 2016 at a VIP reception at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C. with approximately two dozen guests in attendance. The event was a cocktail meet-and-greet, followed by a foreign policy speech delivered by Trump. Kislyak sat in the front row and Trump called for improved Russia-U.S. relations.

Source: Huffington Post

media.caption: Jeff Sessions at a press conference, March 2017

text.headline: Trump Shares Tarmac With Russian Oligarch
text.text:
Dmitry Rybolovlev, who claims to have never met Trump yet purchased a home from him in 2008, lands at the same tarmac at Charlotte Douglas International Airport 90 minutes before Trump landed there for a campaign rally. The jets shared the tarmac for several hours.

Rybolovlev had previously paid an unusually large amount for a Florida mansion Trump had owned. Trump claims to have never met Rybolovlev, and claims he had no idea who paid him $95 million for the mansion.

Source: McClatchy DC

media.caption: 515 N. County Rd., the mansion Dmitry Rybolovlev bought from Donald Trump in 2008
media.credit: Jeffrey Langlois - Palm Beach Daily News

text.headline: Trump Surrogates on Crimea and GOP Platform
text.text:
Then-Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort denies on "Meet The Press" knowing anything about the change in the Republican platform regarding support for Ukraine. That afternoon, Boris Epshteyn, Trump's Russian-born adviser, states the Kremlin's party line telling CNN: "Russia did not seize Crimea. We can talk about the conflict that happened between Ukraine and the Crimea . . . But there was no seizure by Russia. That's an incorrect statement, characterization, of what happened."

Source: NBC News
Source: CNN

text.headline: Trump Team Warns Flynn
text.text:
By late November 2016, senior members of the Trump transition team are aware of Michael Flynn's contacts with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak and personally warn Flynn that Kislyak's conversations are likely being monitored by U.S. intelligence agencies.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Praise For Putin
text.text:
Trump tweets praise for Putin’s statement that Russia will not retaliate against U.S. sanctions.

Source: New York Times
Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump Wants Clinton-Russia Investigation
text.text:
Trump issues a press release about Clinton’s purported Russia connections and tweets a link to same on the day of Vice Presidential Debate.

Source: Donald Trump Press Release

text.headline: Trump Won't Tell Russia Not to Interfere with Election
text.text:
Trump declines to call for Russia to stay out of the U.S. election.

Source: Huffington Post

media.url: “I’m not going to tell Putin what to do. Why should I tell Putin what to do?”
media.caption: Donald Trump to NBC's Matt Lauer

text.headline: Ukranian Associate of Manafort Investigated
text.text:
It is reported that Ukranian-Russian Konstantin Kilimnik, a long-time associate of former Trump campaign CEO Paul Manafort, is being investigated by the FBI and State Department in part because he may have influenced the GOP platform on Russia during the 2016 RNC Convention. Kilimnik made at least two trips to the U.S. in April and during the summer of 2016 and met with Manafort. Both U.S. and Ukraine officials suspect Kilimnik has ties to Russian intelligence, which he denies.

In 2005, Kilimnik was terminated from a decade-long role at the U.S.-based International Republican Institute in Moscow due to suspected Russian ties. He then was hired by Manafort as part of a private equity group that purchased a Ukraine-based cable and internet company from funds provided by Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska. They also worked for Ukrainian oligarch Rinat Akhmetov's businesses, which later led to political work when Akhmetov began funding the campaign of former Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovych. In 2006, Yanukovych was elected prime minister and president in 2010. His political party, the Russian-backed Party of Regions paid Manafort’s firm millions of dollars annually. Kilimnik would go on to run the Kiev office for that firm. Around 2013, the party that arose following the Party of Regions, Opposition Bloc, continued to utilize Manafort's firm. Opposition Bloc stopped paying and Manafort and Kilimnik continued to work together to recoup the unpaid invoices through the time of the U.S. presidential campaign. Kilimnik continues to advise Opposition Bloc.

Source: Politico

text.headline: U.S. Announces Sanctions Against Russia
text.text:
President Barack Obama announces sanctions against Russia for trying to influence the November election through cyberattacks.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: News report concerning President Obama’s announcement of sanctions against Russia

text.headline: U.S. Intelligence, GOP Respond to Trump
text.text:
An extraordinary breach emerges between President-elect Trump and the national security establishment, with Mr. Trump mocking American intelligence assessments that Russia interfered in the election on his behalf, and top Republicans vowing investigations into Kremlin activities.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Vickers on Russian Cyberattacks
text.text:
In a rare public talk, former undersecretary of defense for intelligence Mike Vickers says Russian cyberattacks constituted meddling in the U.S. election and were “beyond the pale.”

Source: NBC News
Source: Yahoo News

media.caption: Michael Vickers, Former Undersecretary of Defense for Intellegence

text.headline: WikiLeaks Publishes Clinton Campaign Emails
text.text:
WikiLeaks claims to be in possession of nearly 50,000 Clinton campaign emails, and on Fri. Oct. 7, it began leaking the personal emails Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta. WikiLeaks said it would release emails every day until Election Day.

Cybersecurity experts said on Nov. 3, 2016, that a group of Russian-linked hackers, had infiltrated Podesta’s email. The Russian Embassy in Washington, D.C., denied via Twitter any role in the cyberattacks.

Source: CBS News
Source: Moyers and Company

text.headline: WikiLeaks Releases First DNC Leak
text.text:
On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, WikiLeaks released its first trove of emails stolen from the DNC by Russians.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Comey and Rogers Testify
text.text:
FBI Director James Comey and National Security Agency Director Mike Rogers testify before the House Intelligence Committee to address public information revealed so far about Russia’s possible ties to the Trump campaign and presidential election.

Source: Time

text.headline: Confirmed: Flynn Discussed U.S. Sanctions
text.text:
The FBI examines Flynn’s communications with Kislyak. U.S. officials confirm that sanctions were discussed.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

text.headline: DOJ Tells White House Flynn Lied
text.text:
Acting Attorney General Sally Yates of the Justice Department notifies White House Counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, that Michael Flynn had not been truthful about his interactions with Sergey Kislyak. Further, she stated Flynn could be at risk for being blackmailed by Russian intelligence. McGahn then briefs Trump.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Sally Yates
media.credit: J. David Ake, Associated Press file

text.headline: F.B.I. has Three Russia Investigations
text.text:
Reuters reports the F.B.I. is pursuing at least three separate probes relating to alleged Russian hacking of the U.S. presidential elections. One investigation is a cyber security investigation to identify the people behind breaches of the Democratic National Committee's computer systems in 2015 and the first half of 2016. The second is an investigation to identify the people who posted emails stolen from Clinton campaign manager John Podesta’s account. The third investigation concerns counterintelligence. F.B.I. agents are pursuing leads related to examination of financial transactions by Russian individuals and companies who are believed to have links to Trump associates.

Source: Reuters

text.headline: FBI Interviews Flynn
text.text:
FBI agents interview Michael Flynn regarding his conversation with Sergey Kislyak.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: FBI Investigates Trump Computer Server
text.text:
As of March 2017, the FBI continues to investigate computer server connections between Russia-based Alfa Bank and the Trump Organization. An Alfa Bank-owned server repeatedly looked up the Trump server’s unique internet address in Summer 2016, accounting for 80 percent of all look-ups to that server during that time period. The investigation is being handled by the same counterintelligence team investigating possible Russian interference into the U.S. presidential election.

Source: CNN

media.caption: Alfa Bank

text.headline: FBI, Senators Hold Private Russia Briefing
text.text:
At the end of the week in which Michael Flynn resigns as National Security Adviser, FBI Director James Comey discusses Russia with members of the Senate Intelligence Committee in a closed-door meeting. Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) attends the meeting and later tweets that he anticipates a bipartisan investigation of Russian interference with the U.S. presidential election will commence.

Source: CNN

text.headline: First Report of Flynn–Kislyak Calls
text.text:
News organizations first report on the call between Michael Flynn and Sergey Kislyak. David Ignatius of The Washington Post questions what Flynn said and wonders if the exchange (1) undercuts the U.S. sanctions against Russia, and (2) violates the spirit of the Logan Act, which bars U.S. citizens from correspondence intending to influence a foreign government about “disputes” with the United States.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn and Pence Discussion
text.text:
Michael Flynn and Mike Pence discuss Flynn's communications with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak. Flynn denies discussing U.S. sanctions on the call with the ambassador.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn Apologizes to Pence
text.text:
Michael Flynn speaks to Mike Pence by phone and is said to have apologized for misleading Pence about the substance of his discussions with Sergey Kislyak.

Source: The Hill

media.caption: Mike Pence and Michael Flynn shaking hands

text.headline: Flynn Cannot Recall Discussing Sanctions
text.text:
Michael Flynn, via his spokesperson, “indicated that while he had no recollection of discussing sanctions [with Sergey Kislyak], he couldn’t be certain that the topic never came up.”

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn Denies Discussing U.S. Sanctions
text.text:
Michael Flynn, during an interview with The Washington Post, denies discussing sanctions with Sergey Kislyak.

Source: Washington Post
Source: New York Times

text.headline: Flynn Resigns as National Security Adviser
text.text:
Michael Flynn resigns as Trump's national security adviser after 24 days on the job.

Source: Michael Flynn's Resignation Letter from New York Times
Source: The New Yorker

text.headline: Flynn Sworn in as National Security Adviser
text.text:
Michael Flynn is sworn in as National Security Adviser. The position does not require Senate confirmation.

Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Flynn Tells Spicer About Kislyak Call
text.text:
Michael Flynn denies talking about sanctions with Sergey Kislyak to Sean Spicer.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Grand jury subpoenas to Flynn associates reported
text.text:
CNN reports that federal prosecutors operating out of the Eastern District of Virginia have issued grand jury subpoenas to Flynn's business associates.

Source: CNN

text.headline: Harward Will not Replace Flynn
text.text:
