Retired Vice Admiral Robert Harward declines Trump's offer to replace Michael Flynn as National Security Adviser after Flynn resigned.

Sources state that Harward declined the role due to financial and family considerations. Additionally, it is reported Trump insisted on retaining pro-Russia Deputy National Security Adviser K.T. McFarland. In 2013, McFarland made a statement that Putin should receive the Nobel Peace Prize. Harward, however, wanted to choose his own staff.

Source: NY Daily News
Source: New York Times

media.caption: Now retired Vice Admiral Harward

text.headline: No Release of Russian Ambassador's Autopsy
text.text:
Whatever caused Russia’s ambassador to the United Nation Vitaly Churkin to suddenly collapse and die at his desk will remain a mystery at the request of Rex Tillerson’s State Department and the Russian consulate. Citing “international law” and requests from the federal government, the New York City Chief Medical Examiner states that no autopsy will be released and asks that all questions be directed to the State Department.

Churkin, age 64, died Feb. 20, 2017, while working at his desk in the consulate’s New York City offices. He served as Russia’s ambassador to the U.N. for more than a decade, and “was a fierce defender of his country’s policies, including Russia’s incursion in Ukraine and its much-criticized bombing of Syria.”

Source: NBC News

media.caption: United Nations in New York City

text.headline: Obama Learns About Flynn’s Russia Contacts
text.text:
In early January, the Obama administration learned of Michael Flynn's late December contacts with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Parts of Dossier Corroborated by U.S. Investigators
text.text:
U.S. investigators announce they have corroborated some communications between senior Russian officials and other Russian individuals, as detailed in a 35-page dossier compiled by a former British intelligence agent. The dossier included allegations that Russian operatives claim to have compromising personal and financial information about Trump.

Source: CNN

text.headline: Peace Plan for Russia and Ukraine
text.text:
Michael Cohen, Special Counsel to the Trump Organization since 2007, hand- delivered a sealed proposal to Michael Flynn's office outlining a way for Trump to lift sanctions against Russia. Cohen has connections to Ukraine through his Ukrainan wife and past family business dealings there. He also participated in deals by the Trump Organization in Russia. The FBI counterintelligence is reviewing his links with Russia.

Michael Cohen, Felix Sater and Andrii Artemenko support the plan. Cohen and Sater said they had not spoken to Mr. Trump about the proposal and have no experience in foreign policy. Artemenko said he had received encouragement for his plans from top Putin aides.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Pence Discusses Flynn-Kislyak Call
text.text:
Mike Pence tells John Dickerson in an interview on Face The Nation that he has spoken with Michael Flynn about Flynn’s communications with Sergey Kislyak. According to Pence, Flynn did not discuss U.S. sanctions against Russia with Kislyak.

“[W]hat I can confirm, having spoken to [Flynn] about it, is that those conversations that happened to occur around the time that the United States took action to expel diplomats had nothing whatsoever to do with those sanctions,” Pence said.

Source: CBS News

media.caption: Full interview of Mike Pence, January 15, 2017

text.headline: President has Confidence in Flynn
text.text:
Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway says Michael Flynn "enjoys the full confidence of the president" and Press Secretary Sean Spicer says the president is “evaluating the situation” in the wake of allegations that Flynn misled Mike Pence about his phone call with Sergey Kislyak. Hours later, Flynn resigns as National Security Adviser.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Priebus Denies Campaign-Russia Connection
text.text:
White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus denied on Fox News that members of Trump’s campaign had contact with Russia before the election and Trump’s win.

He also said, “The New York Times put out an article with no direct sources that said that the Trump campaign had constant contacts with Russian spies, basically, you know, some treasonous type of accusations. We have now all kinds of people looking into this. I can assure you, and I have been approved to say this, that the top levels of the intelligence community have assured me that that story is not only inaccurate, but it’s grossly overstated and it was wrong. And there’s nothing to it.”

Source: The Hill
Source: USA Today

media.caption: Reince Priebus interview on Fox News, February 19, 2017

text.headline: Priebus Discusses Flynn-Kislyak Call
text.text:
In an interview on NBC's Meet The Press, Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, states Michael Flynn and Sergey Kislyak did not discuss U.S. sanctions against Russia.

Source: NBC News
Source: New York Times

media.caption: Interview of Mike Pence, January 15, 2017

text.headline: Report: Russia Interfered to Help Trump
text.text:
The CIA, FBI and NSA release their unclassified report, concluding unanimously, “Vladimir Putin ordered an influence campaign in 2016 aimed at the US presidential election.” The three intelligence agencies agreed that “the Russian Government aspired to help President-elect Trump's election chances when possible.” The report also stated that WikiLeaks had been Russia's conduit for the effort.

Source: Los Angeles Times

media.caption:
The cover page of the intelligence report finding that Putin had, in fact, order
the campaign, and that it signaled a new norm for US-Russia relations.

text.headline: Russian Payments to Flynn not Authorized
text.text:
Acting Secretary of the Army Robert Speer responds via letter to the House Oversight Committee's request for the Pentagon to investigate whether Flynn, a retired Army general, violated Pentagon rules requiring retired officers to report income from foreign states, and states that the Pentagon has not found any documents authorizing Michael Flynn's 2015 Russian government-paid trip to Moscow.

During that trip, Flynn gave a paid interview with the state-run television network, RT, and attended a RT-sponsored gala where he was seated next to Putin.

Source: Fox News

text.headline: Senate Concerned About Russian Cover Up
text.text:
Senator Chuck Schumer (D-NY) says on the Senate floor: “There is real concern that some in the administration may try to cover up its ties to Russia by deleting emails, texts, and other records that could shine a light on those connections. These records are likely to be the subject of executive branch as well as congressional investigations and must be preserved.”

Source: Associated Press

text.headline: Senate investigators request records from Treasury
text.text:
Senator Mark Warner said the Senate's Russia investigators have requested records from the Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) relating to Trump, campaign aides, and Administration officials.

Source: CNN

text.headline: Senate Orders Evidence Preservation
text.text:
The Senate intelligence committee sends formal requests to more than a dozen organizations, agencies, and individuals asking them to preserve all materials related to a probe the committee is conducting on Russian interference in the 2016 election and related issues.

Source: Associated Press

media.caption:
Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer of N.Y. and Sen. Dianne
Feinstein, vice chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Friday, Feb. 17, 2017,
following a closed-door intelligence briefing by FBI Director James Comey

text.headline: Sessions Amends Testimony Again
text.text:
Attorney General Jeff Sessions acknowledges that he encountered Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak a third time, contrary to the prior amendment of his original Congressional testimony where he stated he had only encountered Kislyak twice in the past year. Sessions is forced to amend his testimony again.

Source: Huffington Post

text.headline: Spicer Confirms Flynn-Kislyak Call
text.text:
Sean Spicer confirms the phone conversation between Michael Flynn and Sergey Kislyak. “They exchanged logistical information on how to initiate and schedule [a call between Trump and Putin after the president-elect was sworn in],” Spicer told reporter. “That was it, plain and simple.” He said the call followed a text message exchange initiated by Flynn to wish Kislyak a Merry Christmas.

Source: Bloomberg
Source: New York Times

media.caption:
National Security Adviser nominee Michael Flynn walks in the lobby of Trump Tower
in New York.

text.headline: Spicer Denies Trump Campaign’s Russia Ties
text.text:
When asked whether any Trump associates were in touch with the Russian government prior to the election, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer said at the White House daily briefing, "There's nothing that would conclude me that anything different has changed with respect to that time period."

Source: Mother Jones
Source: USA Today

text.headline: Spicer Talks Flynn at First Press Briefing
text.text:
Sean Spicer, in his first offical press briefing, said he talked to Michael Flynn “last night” once again about Flynn’s communications with Sergey Kislyak. Spicer again stated that Flynn and Kislyak did not discuss U.S. sanctions against Russia.

Source: Chicago Tribune
Source: New York Times

media.caption: Sean Spicer's first white house press briefing, January 23, 2017
media.credit: President Donald Trump Speeches and Press Conference on YouTube

text.headline: Spicer: Trump Does Not Know Page
text.text:
After Carter Page’s name surfaces as one of the Trump campaign’s contacts with Russian operatives, Sean Spicer, then-spokesperson for the Trump transition team, said “Carter Page is an individual whom the President-elect does not know and was put on notice months ago by the campaign.” Carter’s name was mentioned in the dossier of Trump’s connections to Russia; the dossier was compiled by an unnamed former British spy.

Source: USA Today

text.headline: Stone Admits to WikiLeaks Communications
text.text:
While berating journalists and others on Twitter, Trump campaign adviser Roger Stone admitted to having back channel communications with WikiLeaks editor-in-chief Julian Assange to collude in the sabotage of Hillary Clinton's campaign.

Source: Huffington Post

media.caption: Screen shot of a now-deleted Tweet of Roger Stone on March 4, 2017.

text.headline: Trump Claims “Nothing to Do With Russia”
text.text:
At a White House press conference about various topics, Trump responded to questions about Russia. He stated he has “nothing to do with Russia,” had not made any “phone calls to Russia in years,” and doesn't speak to Russians because “I just have nobody to speak to.” He acknowledged having two conversations with Putin, one after the election and one on Inauguration Day. He also stated none of his associates, to his knowledge, have anything to do with Russia.

Regarding former campaign manager Paul Manafort, Trump said Manafort had Ukraine, but not Russian, ties. He praised Manafort as “a good man” who “was replaced long before the election took place.” He repeated Manafort's denial of having any such contact with Russia in response to a follow-up question about whether Manafort was having contact with the Russians in his capacity as Trump's campaign manager,

Trump said, “Russia is a ruse. I have nothing to do with Russia. Haven’t made a phone call to Russia in years. Don't speak to people from Russia. Not that I wouldn’t. I just have nobody to speak to. I spoke to Putin twice. He called me on the election. I told you this. And he called me on the inauguration, a few days ago. We had a very good talk, especially the second one, lasted for a pretty long period of time. I’m sure you probably get it because it was classified. So I’m sure everybody in this room perhaps has it. But we had a very, very good talk. I have nothing to do with Russia. To the best of my knowledge no person that I deal with does. Now, Manafort has totally denied it. He denied it. Now people knew that he was a consultant over in that part of the world for a while, but not for Russia. I think he represented Ukraine or people having to do with Ukraine, or people that -- whoever. But people knew that. Everybody knew that.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Donald Trump at the February 16, 2017 press conference

text.headline: Trump Contradicts Flynn-Kislyak Intel
text.text:
Trump says he has not seen the previous day's news reports that Michael Flynn and Sergey Kislyak discussed sanctions against Russia, contradicting previous statements by the administration about that call.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Trump's press conference on Air Force One, February 10, 2017

text.headline: Trump Denies Connections to Russia
text.text:
Trump told reporters, “I have nothing to do with Russia. To the best of my knowledge, no person that I deal with does.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Trump at a news conference on Feb. 16, 2017.

text.headline: Trump Denies Dealings with Russia
text.text:
Donald Trump tweets a denial that he has any dealings with Russia, including financial ties such as loans and deals.

Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

media.caption: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump Dodges Russia Question
text.text:
Trump did not respond to the final question of his first news conference since the convention when asked if he could affirmatively state that no one connected to him or his campaign had contact with Russia during the campaign. 

Ann Compton of ABC News asked: “Mr. President-elect, can you stand here today, once and for all, and say that no one connected to you or your campaign had any contact with Russia leading up to or during the presidential campaign?” Jim Acosta indicated that Trump answered "no" as he was leaving.

Source: New York Times

media.caption: Ashley Killough of CNN on Twitter

text.headline: Trump Fires Acting AG Yates
text.text:
Acting Attorney General Sally Yates is fired by Trump after announcing that she would not defend his immigration executive order closing U.S. borders to refugees and citizens from seven predominantly Muslim nations. Yates had issued a memo instructing the Justice Department lawyers not to defend the order against legal challenges.

Source: New York Times
Source: Washington Post

text.headline: Trump Fires Comey
text.text:
Trump fires FBI Director James Comey, citing Comey's handling of the Clinton email investigation, and relying on letters from Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein.

The firing comes one day after Comey testified before Congress.

Source: NY Times

text.headline: Trump, Flynn, and Putin Speak
text.text:
Trump and Putin speak for an hour. The call was attended by Michael Flynn.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Says Russia Likely Hacked DNC
text.text:
During his first news conference since the convention, Trump acknowledges that Russia was most likely behind the hacking at the DNC, although he says that “we also get hacked by other countries and other people.”

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Sides With Putin Over Ukraine
text.text:
One day after Trump's call with Putin, renewed fighting breaks out in Ukraine between Russian-backed separatists and Ukraine's military. Trump appears to side with Putin to cast doubt as to whether the Russian government is supporting Russian-backed separatists fighting in eastern Ukraine.

Trump says of the recent clashes, "we don't really know exactly what that is."

The Russian government has denied involvement in the three-year conflict, but there is evidence it has provided equipment and fighters to the separatists; whereas the Ukrainian army has been trained and equipped in part by the U.S.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Trump Takes Oath of Office
text.text:
Trump takes oath as President on Jan. 20, 2017.

Source: New York Times

media.credit: Donald Trump Live Press Conference and Speech 2017 on YouTube

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Disavows Russia Contacts
text.text:
Trump tweets another denial of Russian connections, calling reports of Russian contacts with his campaign were fake news. Once again he relied on Russia’s denials.

Source: USA Today

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Dismisses Dossier
text.text:
Trump tweets: “‘BuzzFeed Runs Unverifiable Trump-Russia Claims’ #FakeNews” in response to the publication by BuzzFeed of a dossier compiled by a former British spy. The dossier details connections between the Trump campaign and Russian government officials and operatives, including Trump.

Source: USA Today

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Doubts DNC Was Hacked
text.text:
Trump tweets: “The Democratic National Committee would not allow the FBI to study or see its computer info after it was supposedly hacked by Russia.....” In a second tweet, he wondered how they know that the DNC was hacked.

Source: The Independent (UK)

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Media Is “Dishonest”
text.text:
Trump tweets defending his reliance on Julian Assange's statements claiming misrepresentation by the media.

Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump Tweets: No Russia Connections
text.text:
Donald Trump tweets another denial that he knows Putin or has deals in Russia.

Source: The Independent (UK)

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Russia Dismisses Dossier
text.text:
Trump relies on statements from Russia to continue denying allegations of connections between himself and Russia made in a dossier compiled by a former British spy.

Source: USA Today

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Russia, WikiLeaks Not Connected
text.text:
Trump tweets his reliance on statements by Julian Assange as a basis for the belief that Russia and WikiLeaks were not connected to the hack of the DNC.

Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump Tweets: Skeptical About Russia Hack
text.text:
Trump tweets his skepticism about Russian hacking based on a delay of an intelligence briefing.

Source: Donald Trump on Twitter

text.headline: Trump: “We Should Trust Putin”
text.text:
Trump told The Times of London he will start his presidency trusting Putin and Germany’s Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Source: The Times (UK)

text.headline: Under Oath, Sessions Denies Russia Contact
text.text:
Responding to questioning during his Senate confirmation hearing, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said under oath, “I’m not aware of any of those activities. I have been called a surrogate at a time or two in [the Trump] campaign and I did not have communications with the Russians.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: Senate confirmation testimony of Jeff Sessions, January 10, 2017

text.headline: U.S. has Intelligence on Collusion
text.text:
Former National Security Agency analyst and counterintelligence officer John Schindler publishes a series of tweets stating that the U.S. has amassed “considerable intelligence” of high-level Russians discussing collusion with Donald Trump’s campaign team.  He added that he was sure an investigation would yield enough evidence to end the Trump administration and “put people in jail.”

Source: The Independent (UK)

text.headline: White House Denies Trump-Russia Contact
text.text:
During a press briefing, White House Deputy Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders denies there were contacts between the Trump campaign and Russians prior to the election. She said, “This is a non-story because to the best of our knowledge, no contacts took place, so it's hard to make a comment on something that never happened.”

Source: USA Today

media.caption: White House deputy press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders in Washington, DC, on March 8, 2017.

text.headline: White House on Flynn–Kislyak Calls
text.text:
In the days following Sally Yate's warning to the White House about Michael Flynn, White House Counsel Donald F. McGahn II reviews the events surrounding the Michael Flynn–Sergey Kislyak phone call and conducts several interviews with Flynn. McGahn determines there are no legal issues related to the call.

Source: New York Times

text.headline: Yates and Clapper Testify About Russia
text.text: Former Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates and former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper testify about Russia's alleged involvement in the 2016 U.S. presidential election before the Senate Judiciary's subcommittee on crime and terrorism Source: CBS News

media.caption: Testimony of Sally Yates and James Clapper at a Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing, May 8, 2017

text.headline: Yates and Officials Discuss Flynn
text.text:
Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates and senior U.S. intelligence and law enforcement officials discuss Michael Flynn's calls with Sergey Kislyak, and whether they should communicate the findings to the incoming Trump administration.

Source: The Hill
